Situation1: There is a scheduled family gathering on the calendar.
Expectation2: Stay updated on changes in laws and legal precedents.
Situation2: The latest issue of a prominent law review journal has arrived, containing articles on developing legal theories. You want to read them.
Story: I glanced at the kitchen clock, the aroma of my daughter’s apple pie already drifting through the house. The family would arrive soon, laughter and stories filling the rooms as they always did during our gatherings. My grandson had called earlier, excited to show me his new science project. I knew how much these moments meant to them—and to me. Yet, on the dining table, the latest law review journal sat unopened, its crisp pages promising insights into evolving legal theories. As a judge, I was expected to stay sharp, to keep up with every nuance and shift in the law. My docket was full next week, and I couldn’t afford to fall behind. The weight of both worlds pressed on me: the warmth of family, the duty of my profession. I felt the tug in my chest, torn between the laughter waiting in the living room and the silent, urgent call of the journal.
